abstracts.cdata!:
The outcomes of the Agricultural
            Extension and Food Production Projects for Nepal were barely
            satisfactory for the agricultural extension program and
            unsatisfactory for the food production program. Both
            projects suffered a number of shortcomings, from design
            through implementation. The project period was set too short
            to implement complex institution-building projects and
            phasing of substantial construction programs was
            unrealistic. Little attention was paid to the availability
            of suitably qualified technical staff and lines of command
            were not clearly delineated. Administrative and budgetary
            problems were not properly identified, the availability of
            relevant technology was ill-assessed, and farmers did not
            participate in the identification and prioritizing of their
            perceived problems and needs. Several key lessons can be
            learned from these projects. First, during the initial years
            of an extension project, little more can be achieved than
            the establishment of an administrative framework. Second, a
            single line of command has to be maintained and management
            performance monitored in systems operation. Third, a
            bottom-up approach to extension and research is essential.
            Fourth, staff have to be provided with adequate incentives
            to ensure motivation and staff continuity. Lastly, staff
            recruitment procedures and training require adequate
            standards to ensure staff quality.
